text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen so the 
holiday season is coming up so I thought I'd share

with you a recipe that would make perfect edible 
gifts these are tiny little melt-in-your-mouth

cookies called kanom ping now kanom means snack 
or dessert and ping means to cook something using

radiant heat sort of the same way you would warm 
your hands over flame you know and it's named

this way because most Thai desserts some of you 
may have noticed does not use radiant heat it's

either boiled or steamed or fried so my guess 
is that this was one of the very first recipes

that uses the technique that nowadays we would 
call baking so it's a super easy dessert and as

a bonus it's gluten free and so addictively 
delicious let's get started so this cookie

recipe is one of the easiest ever it's only got 
five ingredients and really four important ones

now I've got here some coconut milk and what I'm 
going to do is make a very thick coconut syrup so

in addition to that of course some sugar now I'm 
using white sugar here because we want to keep the

cookies color white if you want you can try palm 
sugar and get that butterscotchy flavor in there

but traditionally it's white sugar that we use 
now you can leave the cookies just plain coconut

flavor using the flavor from the coconut milk or 
you can add a little bit of jasmine extract I am

going to use my good old pandan leaf here which is 
nice and aromatic and go super well with coconut

some people just use a drop of vanilla these days 
so I'm going to bring this to a simmer and then

let it simmer gently for about 20 to 30 minutes to 
reduce it into sort of a thick syrupy consistency

now the timing will vary depending on the size of 
your pot and your heat and all that so definitely

keep an eye on it look at this oh look how good 
that is already syrupy coconutty the smell of

pandan leaf is oh so good okay I'm just going 
to take the pandan leaf out and then I'm going

to let the syrup cool just until it's warm is 
doesn't have to be completely cool so the syrup

is cooled so now I'm going to add one egg yolk 
to this and stir it in with my trusty little mini

whisk now you can leave these white or you can 
color these with food coloring and if you just

want one color I'd suggest mixing it in now but if 
you want different colors like me then I will wait

till the dough is done and then separate the dough 
and color them then okay so now there's our liquid

ingredients dry ingredients there's just one thing 
tapioca starch now you can find tapioca starch at

an Asian grocery store comes in a bag like this 
and yes it's upside down I apologize I cut open

the wrong end health food stores also have it 
but those are really expensive so if you can

look for this at an Asian grocery store okay at my 
local store this is one dollar a bag versus seven

dollars a bag crazy right yes so now super easy 
I'm going to pour my liquid ingredients into my

tapioca starch make sure you use a rubber spatula 
to scrape every last bit in there so now I'm just

going to use my hands and knead everything 
together there's still a little bit warm this

part feels so good and it's going to feel like 
there's not enough liquid in the beginning but

just give it time takes the tapioca starch a bit 
of time to absorb all that liquid now this recipe

because it involves reducing a liquid everyone's 
going to end up at different volumes different

amount of liquid so you may end up needing to add 
a little bit more flour a little bit more water

and that's just something you'll have to see at 
the end the trickiest part about this recipe is

how moist or how dry the dough needs to be and so 
the first batch is going to be a bit of a test run

for you however if you do feel like it's way too 
dry don't add a splash of water because the dough

does not need a lot of water so what you'll do is 
you need a spray bottle and just put in thank you

put in just a couple of spritz and then need that 
in it really doesn't need that much more sometimes

okay so now my dough is more or less well mixed 
I'm going to divide it into three different block

so I can have three different colors there we go 
and since it's the holiday season I'm gonna make

pink and green and white webs a couple of drops 
of my red food coloring and need that in alright

beautiful so now once you're done mixing the 
dough you want the dough to rest for about half

an hour and I find that resting period allows the 
starch to fully absorb the liquid and it does make

a difference to the texture at the end kinome 
peeing is usually just tiny little bite-sized

pieces so what you want is just about this big 
and this will puff up a little bit they look

tiny right now but I find the tiny ones so cute 
you can make them bigger if you want that's it

as simple as that I'm using a silicone sheet so 
that they don't stick you can also do parchment

paper and it doesn't have to be perfectly round 
right now that will even itself out in the oven

and now these are going to go into a 350 degree 
oven for 25 to 30 minutes now they won't Brown

very much but you can tell they're done when the 
bottoms are brown and the white ones you can tell

it's starting to get a little bit of color but 
these won't Brown as much a say a wheat cookie

because that's just the nature of tapioca starch 
so we'll be right back look how cute these are

they've been in the oven for about thirty minutes 
they've browned a little bit on the bottom again

they don't Brown very much in general and these 
little cracks have formed which I love now if

your dough is a little bit on the moist side 
there won't be any cracks can they'll spread a

little bit more but there's not that snot wrong 
okay there's a lot of comping that don't have

any cracks and the texture will actually be a 
little lighter so these because the dough was

on the dry side it has these cute little cracks 
and it'll be a little denser when you eat them

okay here's one last trick I'm going to give you 
and I kind of discovered this by accident if you

want an even light a more brittle texture instead 
of letting these cool outside let them cool in the

oven that you've turned off and that residual heat 
will continue to sort of dry them out and that's

how they become super super brittle so you know 
you've got time definitely do that and if you're

serving these at a party just pop them in a little 
Bowl alternate the colors they are so cute these

because they're so small super addictive look 
how pretty the green didn't show up as much as

I thought but the pink certainly did time to eat 
one I could use a nice cup of tea or coffee to

go with these if you've never had these before 
it is a texture like nothing else they crumble

and are brittle kind of like a meringue cookie 
and as you start chewing them they sort of melt

and turn into this creamy coconutty goodness 
in your mouth and it's it's really something

you have to experience in order to know what 
I mean so I hope you give these little guys

of try when you make it send me a photo on 
Facebook Twitter or Instagram the recipe as

always will be on hot Thai Kitchen comm and I 
will see you next time for your next delicious

time this recipe only have five ingredients 
it's so cozy only has only has five increase
